questions.neutral: Did you make it through the day?

hobby.message: Is analog photography still worth the risk?
Still flying like no one's watching?
Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Made it through. Stuck to my routine for most of it.
Worked a bit, kept busy outside.
Shot a few photos here and there. Nothing out of place.
Crowds felt different today.
Day was alright, though tense out on the street.
Managed to grab a few shots—analog, nothing digital these days.
My film camera keeps me busy.
Harder lately, people notice when you’re looking.
Neighborhoods changing. Makes my hobby... interesting.
Yeah, just made it. Actually managed to shoot some film downtown.
Analog is my thing—old 35mm, shoots quietly, no tracking.
It’s been wild since the free zones started up.
Caught a council meeting on film, just for myself.
People aren’t hiding anymore. That’s new.
Brings out something raw you can’t fake.
Just barely made it through, honestly, but it was worth it.
Spent hours with my film camera—no screens, pure instinct.
Snapped people forming those street councils, right out in the open.
Feels like shooting a new world sometimes.
Used to hide my camera. Today, folks invited me to capture it.
I process everything in my flat. Risky but real.
Even got stopped, but all smiles. It’s changing how I see Stenograd.
Long day, but my kind of day—you know I shoot street photos, right?
All analog—smuggled 35mm, won’t touch digital, not with this place wired.
The free zones make it easy to get what matters—raw truth, no edits.
Spent hours in Kirov district, people didn’t care about the BCI for once.
Shot rolls of neighbors making their own rules, just being seen.
When the system worked, my hobby felt like subversion. Now? It’s community, almost.
Had to hide my negatives in coffee tins like my father did.
One guy told me: ‘We’re real, now you prove it.’ Couldn’t invent that energy.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still shooting analog. Haven't switched yet.
Film's harder to get now with all the closures.
I just stick to quieter spots, keep out of the way.
Everyone's tense since those councils popped up.
Mostly keep the camera hidden, can't be sure who's watching.
Still using the old camera.
I get what I need when I can find spare film.
The free zones mean people don't bark at me as much.
Still, nobody likes to be a subject these days.
Caught a council meeting last week, but didn't stay long.
Can't trust who's passing through, not with the BCI misfires.
I am, actually. Film's still my vice—can't fake truth on 35mm.
Harsh getting supplies, but neighbors swap me rolls for old prints.
The new free zones made street shots easier, people aren't ducking as much.
I photographed an open council the other day. Felt strange, like history was rewriting itself.
Still, I watch my back. Some don't like a lens on their uprising.
After Halden died, scenes on the street changed overnight.
It's the honesty in those moments that pulls me back.
Absolutely. Analog’s the only thing that feels real now.
Since Halden, people in the street trade smuggled film like cigarettes.
Last week, I shot open council meetings—nobody flinched, just looked me right in the eye.
It's risky, but the BCI glitches mean guards ignore me half the time.
There's this energy—everyone organizing, even the skeptics want to be in the frame.
Can't process anything at work, but neighbors help with chemicals.
I see faces easing, less fear, just possibility.
Feels like something big, and a part of me saves every frame.
Always. My father hated my camera—said seeing too much is dangerous here.
But these weeks? No digital oversight, analog is alive again.
I even borrowed film last weekend from an ex-colleague—sharing, not reporting.
Photographed a team splitting bread with old BCI rivals. No one looked away.
The sudden honesty in these free zones—it’s addictive.
With the BCI scrambled, I trade prints for stories instead of rations.
Sometimes I worry about saving too much proof, but I can’t stop.
I almost got caught near a protest—except now, who’s keeping count?
Feels like my lens is chronicling a city waking up, not hiding anymore.
